Award.AwardTitle: Doctoral Dissertation Research: Making Democracy Work for Women: Gender Gaps in Political Participation and Representation

Directorate.LongName: Direct For Social, Behav & Economic Scie

Division.LongName: Divn Of Social and Economic Sciences

Award.AbstractNarration:
General Summary
Despite legal guarantees of equality, stark gaps in political participation and representation persist between men and women in democracies around the world. Evidence from advanced industrialized democracies shows that when women participate in higher numbers as voters (e.g. after the extension of suffrage rights), it produces policy shifts in line with their political preferences. However, it is unclear whether similar outcomes result in developing contexts where women?s voting rights are guaranteed in the constitution as a result of elite, rather than popular consensus. In this project, the PI draws on evidence from a developing democracy with persistent gender inequality, to show that voting rights are at best unevenly exercised by women. Certain additional conditions must be present for increased participation to produce improved representation: notably the independence of women's vote and the credible potential for collective action by women. By identifying the conditions under which women's preferences are equally represented in policymaking, the project findings can inform policy aimed to achieve women's political equality and improve the representation of marginalized voices in politics.

Technical Summary:
This project addresses a question that is central to political science theories of democratic representation and of substantive interest to policymakers and advocates for women?s rights: under what conditions does the equal exercise of a de jure right to participate produce de facto equality of representation for women? While this is a quintessential question in the study of democracy, rarely has it been examined outside the context of the developed world. This project fills this empirical gap by generating evidence on the actual content of women?s preferences in a developing democracy, and makes a contribution to democratic theory by identifying the conditions under which increased electoral participation by a group leads to more direct representation of their preferences in policy decisions. The PI uses original survey and behavioral data collected from citizens and representatives, supplemented by electoral and administrative data collected from government departments and data on women's mobilization collected from local NGOs to test the theoretical predictions. The PI also draws on semi-structured interviews with local government representatives, political party workers and civil society members to develop appropriate measures of key concepts and to contextualize the results of quantitative findings.

POR.DRECONTENT:
In democracies around the world, despite legal guarantees of equality, women face barriers to equal political participation and representation. This project develops and tests a theory about how the equal representation of women’s preferences in a democracy depends on 1) the level of women’s participation, and 2) whether such participation is “independent” and truly reflective of their distinctive preferences. Importantly, this second condition is unlikely to be satisfied in contexts where gender inequality is high.  The project thus sheds light on the conditions under which women’s political participation as voters and citizens can be expected to produce meaningful political changes in line with their preferences. 


Fieldwork for the project was conducted in Pakistan (Islamabad, Lahore and Faisalabad) over the course of twelve months during 2016-2019. During this time, I collected administrative electoral data on gender gaps in voter registration and turnout from the 2013 and 2018 national elections, and the 2015 local government elections. I also conducted semi-structured interviews with officials at the National Election Commission, political party members, elected local government representatives, and relevant office holders. I collected primary documents related to voter education and mobilization efforts. Finally, I conducted a survey in 800 households documenting the intra-household gender gaps in political participation, attitudes towards women’s political activity, and preferences over public goods and service delivery. As part of this survey, I also developed and implemented a new behavioral measure of preference expression.


Using the administrative data, the project documents descriptive patterns of gender gaps in political participation, and identifies an empirical puzzle of the highest gaps in voter turnout being in large metropolitan cities in Pakistan. This finding was shared with policy stakeholders in the lead-up to the 2018 national elections to inform the targeting of efforts to improve women’s turnout. Secondly, the survey confirms that men and women have distinctive preferences over local service provision and that these map onto the gendered division of labor within the household. Finally it finds evidence of a stark gap between men and women’s willingness to express these distinctive preferences, and that this gap is exacerbated when women have lower decision-making power in the household and do not work outside the home. 


The findings deepen our understanding of the gender gap in political participation, providing evidence for the idea that the gap exists not just in levels but also the extent to which participation reflects distinctive preferences. The lessons from Pakistan are instructive for other gender-unequal contexts: increased participation by women may not produce the expected gains in the representation until the barriers to women’s free expression are also removed.
